title: The Premier League history Leicester made with 9-0 Southampton walloping
text:
Jamie Vardy, Youri Tielemans and Ayoze Perez all scored at St Mary’s (Picture: Getty Images)

Leicester City set a new record on Friday night, securing the biggest away win in Premier League history with a 9-0 destruction of Southampton.

The Foxes were in rampant mood at St Mary’s capitalising on the red card for Ryan Bertrand just 12 minutes in to completely demolish their hosts on the south coast.

There were hat-tricks for Ayoze Perez and Jamie Vardy, while Ben Chilwell, Youri Tielemans and James Maddison also got on the score sheet.

The incredible result is the biggest away win, not only in the Premier League, but in top flight history.

9-0 also matched the record for the biggest ever Premier League win, with Manchester United also beating Ipswich 9-0 back in March 1995.

No team had ever scored nine goals away from home in the Premier League before, with only one side netting eight on the road before, when Manchester United hammered Nottingham Forest 8-1 at the City Ground in 1999.

Southampton had never even conceded seven goals in a Premier League game before, but that record has been blown out of the water.

Only once before in the Premier League have two players scored a hat-trick for the same team, with Robert Pires and Jermaine Pennant both netting three times for Arsenal, also against Southampton in 2003.

The Foxes are also only the second team to be 5-0 ahead at half-time in an away game, following Manchester City at Burnley in 2010.

On the achievement of biggest ever away win, Vardy told Sky Sports: ‘We found out at 6-0 when Jonny Evans came sprinting over saying if we carry on doing what we’re doing then we can beat the record.’
